gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
# US Drought Monitor — October 15, 2002
## Introduction
## Hawaii Despite some recent rains over the mid-section of the Hawaiian Islands, accumulated deficits are beginning to have an impact over western Molokai, especially for agricultural operations. Moderate drought (D1) has been introduced into this area. Abnormally dry (D0) conditions remain over Maui and Oahu.
## The Mid-Atlantic and Southeast After missing out on the bulk of remnant hurricane rainfall each of the past two weeks, most of the Atlantic Seaboard welcomed widespread beneficial rains this last week. From central Georgia up to Long Island, rainfall reports of 2 to 4 inch soakings were widespread. Rain was heaviest (6 +) off the southeast coast (and just inland) as the formerly stronger Kyle sat off the Carolina and Georgia coastlines. This rainfall helped to start eroding away at the drought along the coastal areas of Georgia, the Carolinas and Virginia. While the rains were not as heavy further inland (or on the western Appalachian front), they were good enough to remove the exceptional (D4) drought in the Carolinas and southern Virginia. They also led to the reduction of the core area of extreme (D3) drought in the same region. Accordingly, the D0 and D1 areas were also reduced and pushed inland off of their respective coasts. Guarded optimism is the general rule here as overall improvement in the region this week is reflected by a general tightening and pushing (one category improvement) of the drought boundaries westward off the coastal stretches in the Carolinas and eastern Virginia. The rains brought a welcome reversal to an intensification pattern (dry) that was re-emerging in the region earlier this fall. While short-term numbers are positive, the region is still dealing with a drought of long-term proportions as year-to-date deficits still fall in the 6-12 inch range. Going back to October of 2001, we see many locations still facing deficits of 12-18 inches from southeast Georgia and east-central Alabama up through the Carolinas and into Virginia and Maryland. On the western front of the drought, Montgomery (-15.75/66% of normal) and other parts of east-central Alabama have seen deficits of 10-15 inches accumulate since January 1, 2002. This has once again led to an expansion of moderate drought (D1) into east-central Alabama. Fire danger has been reduced and top soil moisture conditions have improved considerably over the past few weeks leading to a removal of the A and F impact labels in the East. The recent rains have resulted in the region falling exclusively under the W (water/hydro) impact delineation. This signifies that while many areas have reduced their short-term deficits and resultant impacts, the long-term drought and its impacts will still persist unless this recent favorable wet trend continues over the coming weeks and months. Ground water levels remain at record lows at many locations and streamflow and reservoir levels need to continue to improve.
## The Ohio Valley, Great Lakes, and Northeast After back to back weeks of beneficial tropical moisture, the Ohio Valley and Great Lakes regions reverted to a much more typical fall week as drier weather settled in. In the Northeast, some locations in the lower New England area received moderate rainfall amounts on the order of an inch or two. As a result, abnormally dry (D0) conditions have now been pushed further south in New York and eastward in both Massachusetts and Connecticut.
## The Plains and the West After seeing improvement in drought conditions last week over many parts of the Plains, virtually all locations west of the Missouri River saw little to nothing in the form of precipitation last week. An exception to this was the Red River (and its basin), which forms the border between Oklahoma and Texas. One to two inches was reported across parts of south central Oklahoma, north central Texas and over to the southwestern Arkansas border. Abnormally dry conditions have been removed from this area and the A,W impact line has moved westward to now follow and form the eastern edge of the drought in the West. Further north, increases in D2 to D4 coverage were seen in parts of western Nebraska. A few locations are on pace to set near-record, or record lows for annual precipitation and are currently at near-record or record low year-to-date totals (with some records going back to the late 1800s). In addition, an area of moderate drought (D1) that has developed over the last 90 days in northeast Oklahoma, northwest Arkansas and southwest Missouri has pushed northward and is now joined with the area of D1 coverage previously found at points northward in Nebraska, eastern Kansas and western Missouri. After a good start to the snow season in some places in the West (along w/ some minor improvements), most of the mountain ranges saw no significant snowfall last week so the situation remains unchanged as we are only beginning the new water year (Oct. 1-to-date).
## Forecast Conditions forecast to affect current areas of dryness and drought during October 16-25 include: 1) a rather vigorous low pressure system should bring more drought relief by the middle of this week (Oct.15 and Oct.16) in the way of blustery weather as moderate-to-heavy rainfall amounts of two inches or more should spread out across the East (heaviest along the Appalachians from western Georgia up into the Carolinas and Virginia) and up into the Northeast; 2) high pressure (ridging) should result in little, if any, precipitation across most of the West. Above-normal temperatures should accompany this ridging pattern, especially in the Pacific NW; 3) a cold front will move slowly across the countrys mid-section over the weekend bringing above-normal chances of precipitation from New Mexico all the way across the Deep South and into the Southeast. This system will bring with it the potential for 1 to 2 inches of rain in the Southern Plains over to the Appalachians and up into New England which could bring more relief to the western front of the drought in the East; 4) most of the entire eastern two-thirds of the country can expect to see colder than normal temperatures due to dominant high pressure and colder Canadian air.
## Disclaimer The discussion in the Looking Ahead section is simply a description of what the official national guidance from the National Weather Service (NWS) National Centers for Environmental Prediction is depicting for current areas of dryness and drought. The NWS forecast products utilized include the HPC 5-day QPF and 5-day Mean Temperature progs, the 6-10 Day Outlooks of Temperature and Precipitation Probability, and the 8-14 Day Outlooks of Temperature and Precipitation Probability, valid as of late Wednesday afternoon of the USDM release week. The NWS forecast web page used for this section is: https://www.cpc.ncep.noaa.gov/products/forecasts/.
